Award.AwardTitle: Portable and Persistent Autonomous Real-Time Marine Mammal Acoustic Monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Proposal was submitted to the National Ocean Partnership Program (NOPP) Broad Agency Announcement 10-024 titled "Marine Mammal Detection and Monitoring" and selected for funding by NSF.

The PI's request funding to integrate existing technologies, namely the Bioacoustics Research Program (BRP) marine autonomous recording unit ("Pop-Up") hardware, and detection, classification, and localization (DCL) software into a wave-powered glider towing a small array. An autonomous marine mammal monitoring system will be developed that includes a broadband satellite communications system that would be capable of transmitting detection, classification, and localization data in near real-time to an on-ship or onshore Data Management and Communications (DMAC) receiver.

Broader Impacts:

Successful development of the proposed system has the potential to provide a lower cost method for monitoring marine mammals in areas that would otherwise not be surveyed. Monitoring and understanding the impacts of anthropogenic noise on marine mammals is becoming more important as human induced sound in the marine environment increases. The system could potentially lower the cost of monitoring because it will not require a local ship for its deployment or retrieval and it reduces the steps needed for data analyses by broadcasting data over the Satcom link and providing initial DCL measures prior to human data processing. The potential for transferring data via the broadband satellite link will be a huge boon for the community as currently limited bandwidth inhibits progress in DCL.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Noise in the ocean from man-made activities - like oil and gas exploration, cargo shipping, and naval exercises – have negative impacts on marine mammals ranging from disrupting their communication with each other to causing hearing loss. If the noise continues and their communication is disrupted for long periods, it may impact their feeding, migration, and reproduction. To assess the effects of man-made noise in the ocean, and use that information to reduce the impact on marine mammals, people use either anchored underwater sound recorders, or underwater microphones towed behind ships. However, both of these have major drawbacks that make them ineffective for preventing harm to marine mammals.

Sounds on underwater recorders are analyzed months after the man-made sound occurred and have already caused problems for the marine mammals, so they are useless for prevention. Recordings from underwater microphones towed by ships are corrupted by the noise of the tow ship and any nearby man-made sounds, plus they are expensive because they require a large ship with space for a lot of computer and manpower on board to manage the operation of the towed underwater microphones. Rather than only being able to look at the past damage we may have inflicted on marine mammals with noise, we should move to a system that allows us to monitor ocean noise in real-time so we can prevent harm to those animals.

This project developed an unmanned gliding vehicle that can record ocean sounds, identify whale calls in those recorded sounds, and send those whale calls over satellite to a person in a matter of seconds for real-time decisions to be made about altering man-made activities in the ocean to prevent harm to marine mammals. The foundation of this system is the Wave Glider, built by Liquid Robotics, a wave-powered unmanned vehicle. Solar panels on the floating part of the Wave Glider charge the on-board batteries to provide power for the recording electronics, and an underwater finned portion of the glider tows the underwater microphones almost silently through the water.

Sea tests have demonstrated that the system can record from four underwater microphones at once, while transmitting portions of the recordings that it thinks are whale sounds via satellite to a person who can listen and confirm the presence of whales. We developed the electronics for the sound recording and satellite transmission, as well as the software to display the sounds and their direction relative to the Wave Glider on the listener’s computer screen. The system was demonstrated in a two-week test in Cape Cod Bay during April and May of 2014, and its power use during that test indicated that the system could be used for up to 60 days at a time before needing to be retrieved by boat and recharged.
